It's meant as a bird's-eye-view of network metrics and some standard visualization forms, a way of exploring network data in classroom or research settings. Our intention is to emphasize the useful measurements and statistics that can be drawn from network data, while still providing the visualization tools offered by other network analysis software. *Network Navigator* was first released in 2017; the site was redesigned, expanded, and re-released as v2.0 in 2021. + +![](img/upload_data.gif) + +For more info, check out the [About](https://network-navigator.library.cmu.edu/about.html) and [How-To](https://network-navigator.library.cmu.edu/how-to.html) pages on our site."}, {'sha': '71964171ef4bf4b165e0397648fe9700f048ce3c', 'filename': 'about.html', 'status': 'added', 'additions': 59, 'deletions': 0, 'changes': 59, 'blob_url': 'https://github.com/jrladd/network_navigator/blob/8887cd12297a98c43792792d92d76f061c9f33e9/about.html', 'raw_url': 'https://github.com/jrladd/network_navigator/raw/8887cd12297a98c43792792d92d76f061c9f33e9/about.html', 'contents_url': 'https://api.github.com/repos/jrladd/network_navigator/contents/about.html?ref=8887cd12297a98c43792792d92d76f061c9f33e9', 'patch': '@@ -0,0 +1,59 @@ + + + + + + + + Network Navigator + + + + + + + + +
+
+

+ NETWORK NAVIGATOR v2.0 +

+
+
+
+

Network Navigator is a browser tool designed for network analysis, built with humanities data in mind. It's meant as a bird's-eye-view of network metrics and some standard visualization forms, a way of exploring network data in classroom or research settings. Our intention is to emphasize the useful measurements and statistics that can be drawn from network data, while still providing the visualization tools offered by other network analysis software. Network Navigator was first released in 2017; the site was redesigned, expanded, and re-released as v2.0 in 2021.

+

This website does not collect or store any data. Your data remains on your computer alone and is not sent to an external server. No one can view your data or results but you.

+ +

People

+
+ +

John Ladd

+
+

John is a postdoctoral fellow in Digital Humanities at Northwestern University. He specializes in network analysis and computational approaches to early modern literature. He's also worked on EarlyPrint, Six Degrees of Francis Bacon, and a range of other projects.

+

Website. Twitter. Github. +

+ +

Zoe LeBlanc

+
+

Zoe is currently a Postdoctoral Associate and Weld Fellow at the Center for Digital Humanities at Princeton University. She received her Ph.D. in History at Vanderbilt University in August 2019 and previously worked as a DH Developer at the Scholars' Lab at UVA.

+

Website. Twitter. Github. + +

Credits

+

We would like to thank Ruth and Sebastian Ahnert, Dan Evans, Doug Knox, Matt Lincoln, Steve Pentecost, Melanie Walsh, and Scott Weingart for their inspiration, suggestions, and feedback on this project.

+

Hosting and technical support for Network Navigator is generously supplied by:

+

+ +

Code

+

The complete code for this site can be found in its Github repository.

+

Network Navigator makes use of the following libraries and stylesheets:

+

JSNetworkX, for calculating network metrics.

+

D3, for interactive visualizations.

+

DataTables, for handling tabular data and CSV export.

+

Tachyons, for styling and page layout.

+

Last Updated: March 2021

+

+
+

+ NETWORK NAVIGATOR v2.0 +

+
+
+
+

How-To

+

This page will walk you through the basics of Network Navigator, the browser tool designed for network metrics and visualization.

+ +

Load Data

+ + +

To load data into Network Navigator, type or drag-and-drop your edge list into the box. Use a CSV file or type your edges separated by commas, as below. (If you include a header row, the site will look for source, target, and weight columns, and it will keep track of any other columns you enter.)

+ +

+ Person One,Person Two +Person Two,Person Three +Person Three,Person One

+ +

Your network can be either weighted or unweighted, and either directed or undirected. If your network is weighted, you'll need to add a third column to every line with the weight value:

+ +

Person One,Person Two,5

+ +

This site will work best with networks of up to 500 nodes and up to 10,000 edges, but networks of 250-500 edges will give the best visualization results. Networks larger than 500 nodes and ~10,000 edges may result in some slowdown of site functions.

+ +

n.b.: Network Navigator is currently only set up for unimodal (or unipartite) networks. While it will give results for any edge list, be advised that the metrics for bipartite networks aren't reliable.

+ +

Once you've typed or drag-and-dropped your data into the textbox and selected the appropriate options, you can click "Navigate" to display the dashboard for your network.

+ +

Read Results

+ +

Clicking "Navigate" will load the network dashboard, with metrics on the left and visualizations on the right. If you need to make changes to the underlying data, you can scroll up to get to the original textbox, make your adjustments, and click "Navigate" again to start over.

+ + +

You can collapse either the Metrics or Visualizations sides of the dashboard to get a better view of the data. On the metrics side, you will see a short list of global network metrics, a histogram showing the frequency distribution of different node-level metrics, and a table showing each node and its metric values. (You'll also see download options, which we discuss below.)

+ + +

Clicking on the options above the histogram bar chart will show different graphs for each selected metric. These buttons will also update the size of the nodes in the force layout and arc diagram visualizations.

+ + +

Searching for specific nodes in the data table will also filter the visualization, making it easier to find the node you're looking for.

+ +

Read results with care! Some metrics will be affected by the type of graph you select. For example, in many smaller directed graphs, eigenvector centrality will be 0 for every node. Though this looks like an error, it's due to the nature of eigenvector centrality. When possible, Network Navigator displays error messages to explain some of these special cases.

+ +

Customize Visualizations

+ + +

One the right side of the screen, you have three different options for visualizations: clicking on "Force Layout," "Arc Diagram," and "Adjacency Matrix" will display these visualization types.

+ + +

You can scroll to zoom the Force Layout and Arc Diagram. In the Adjacency Matrix, you can click and drag to draw a box around the area you'd like to zoom into. In all visualizations, click the "Restore Zoom" button to return to the original display.

+ + +

Clicking "Customize Graph" will open a menu, different for each visualization type, that gives options for changing the appearance of the network. You can update the size or color of nodes, hide and show labels, change the order of nodes, and more.

+ + +

If your data had a header row and included more edge attributes, like edge weights, edge types, or timespans, you can filter the Force Layout and Arc Diagram based on those attributes. Select your desired attribute under "Filter by edge attribute" and navigate through the menus that appear.

+ +

Export and Download

+ + +

On the left side of the screen, beneath the global network metrics, is a set of options for downloading visualizations and data. Choose an option to download: a PNG or SVG of your current visualization view, a PNG of the current histogram, or a TXT file containing the global network metrics.

+ + +

You can also download the full node table as a CSV. To do this, scroll down to the node table and click "Download as CSV." You can also copy the data to the clipboard.

+ +

Last Updated: July 2021

+ +
+

Network Navigator is designed to give you a first glimpse of your network data, with both metrics and visualizations. For more on who we are and how the site works, visit our About and How-To pages.

+ +

Type or drag-and-drop your edge list into the box. Use a CSV file or type your edges separated by commas, as below. (If you include a header row, the site will look for source, target, and weight columns.)

+ +

+ + Person One,Person Two + Person Two,Person Three + Person Three,Person One

+ +

Your network can be either weighted or unweighted, and either directed or undirected. If your network is weighted, you'll need to add a third column to every line with the weight value:

+ +

Person One,Person Two,5

+ +

This site will work best with networks of up to 500 nodes and up to 10,000 edges, but networks of 250-500 edges will give the best visualization results. Networks larger than 500 nodes and ~10,000 edges may result in some slowdown of site functions.

+ +

n.b.: Network Navigator is currently only set up for unimodal (or unipartite) networks. While it will give results for any edge list, be advised that the metrics for bipartite networks aren't reliable.

+ +

This website does not collect or store any data. Your data remains on your computer alone and is not sent to an external server. No one can view your data or results but you. +

+ +

If you have comments or suggestions, or if anything's not working the way it should, feel free to reach out to John on Twitter.

r=V(e,b.cssClasses.connects);u=[],(s=[]).push(M(r,t[0]));for(var n=0;n + + + + + + + Network Navigator + + + + + + + + +
+
+

+ NETWORK NAVIGATOR v2.0 +

+
+
+
+ +

Resources & Next Steps

+ +

For more information about managing network data and an introduction to the various network metrics used here, we recommend two Programming Historian tutorials: +

Creating Network Diagrams from Historical Sources

+

Exploring and Analyzing Network Data with Python

+
+

If you have bipartite or bimodal network data (a network that includes 2 kinds of entities, like one of authors and their books), you will need to project your data before you use Network Navigator. There is a quick tool for transforming your data here: +

The Project Project

+
+

Once you've explored your network on our site, you may want to move to a more robust set of network analysis and visualization tools. We recommend the following:

+

NetworkX, a Python library

+

iGraph, an R library

+

Gephi, a desktop program

+

Cytoscape, a desktop program

+

D3 Force-Directed Graph, a JavaScript library with tools for network visualization

+
+

For general guidance on network analysis and Python cultural analytics approaches, we recommend Melanie Walsh's Introduction to Cultural Analytics & Python and John Ladd's EarlyPrint + Python.

+ +

Last Updated: April 2021

+
+ + +'}]

Network Navigator is a browser tool designed for network analysis, built with humanities data in mind. It's meant as a bird's-eye-view of network metrics and some standard visualization forms, a way of exploring network data in classroom or research settings. Network Navigator was first released in 2017; the site was redesigned, expanded, and re-released as v2.0 in 2021.

+

Network Navigator is a browser tool designed for network analysis, built with humanities data in mind. It's meant as a bird's-eye-view of network metrics and some standard visualization forms, a way of exploring network data in classroom or research settings. Our intention is to emphasize the useful measurements and statistics that can be drawn from network data, while still providing the visualization tools offered by other network analysis software. Network Navigator was first released in 2017; the site was redesigned, expanded, and re-released as v2.0 in 2021.

This website does not collect or store any data. Your data remains on your computer alone and is not sent to an external server. No one can view your data or results but you.

People

@@ -40,21 +40,6 @@

Zoe LeBlanc

Zoe is currently a Postdoctoral Associate and Weld Fellow at the Center for Digital Humanities at Princeton University. She received her Ph.D. in History at Vanderbilt University in August 2019 and previously worked as a DH Developer at the Scholars' Lab at UVA.

Website. Twitter. Github. -

Next Steps

- -

For more information about managing network data and an introduction to the various network metrics used here, we recommend two Programming Historian tutorials: -

Creating Network Diagrams from Historical Sources

-

Exploring and Analyzing Network Data with Python

-

Once you've explored your network on our site, you may want to move to a more robust set of network analysis and visualization tools. We recommend the following:

-

NetworkX, a Python library

-

iGraph, an R library

-

Gephi, a desktop program

-

Cytoscape, a desktop program

-

D3 Force-Directed Graph, a JavaScript library with tools for network visualization

- -

For general guidance on network analysis and Python cultural analytics approaches, we recommend Melanie Walsh's Introduction to Cultural Analytics & Python and John Ladd's EarlyPrint + Python.

- -

Credits

We would like to thank Ruth and Sebastian Ahnert, Dan Evans, Doug Knox, Matt Lincoln, Steve Pentecost, Melanie Walsh, and Scott Weingart for their inspiration, suggestions, and feedback on this project.

Hosting and technical support for Network Navigator is generously supplied by:

'}, {'sha': 'e0f36cc011a584321097aa3ae040bcc28ba6f5fb', 'filename': 'how-to.html', 'status': 'added', 'additions': 90, 'deletions': 0, 'changes': 90, 'blob_url': 'https://github.com/jrladd/network_navigator/blob/3de065a067aa694fc37014c6536502a9e1448c01/how-to.html', 'raw_url': 'https://github.com/jrladd/network_navigator/raw/3de065a067aa694fc37014c6536502a9e1448c01/how-to.html', 'contents_url': 'https://api.github.com/repos/jrladd/network_navigator/contents/how-to.html?ref=3de065a067aa694fc37014c6536502a9e1448c01', 'patch': '@@ -0,0 +1,90 @@ + + + + + + + + Network Navigator How-To + + + + + + + + +
+
+

+ NETWORK NAVIGATOR v2.0 +

+
+
+
+

How-To

+

This page will walk you through the basics of Network Navigator, the browser tool designed for network metrics and visualization.

+ +

Load Data

+ + +

To load data into Network Navigator, type or drag-and-drop your edge list into the box. Use a CSV file or type your edges separated by commas, as below. (If you include a header row, the site will look for source, target, and weight columns, and it will keep track of any other columns you enter.)

+ +

+ Person One,Person Two +Person Two,Person Three +Person Three,Person One

+ +

Your network can be either weighted or unweighted, and either directed or undirected. If your network is weighted, you'll need to add a third column to every line with the weight value:

+ +

Person One,Person Two,5

+ +

This site will work best with networks of up to 500 nodes and up to 10,000 edges, but networks of 250-500 edges will give the best visualization results. Networks larger than 500 nodes and ~10,000 edges may result in some slowdown of site functions.

+ +

n.b.: Network Navigator is currently only set up for unimodal (or unipartite) networks. While it will give results for any edge list, be advised that the metrics for bipartite networks aren't reliable.

+ +

Once you've typed or drag-and-dropped your data into the textbox and selected the appropriate options, you can click "Navigate" to display the dashboard for your network.

+ +

Read Results

+ +

Clicking "Navigate" will load the network dashboard, with metrics on the left and visualizations on the right. If you need to make changes to the underlying data, you can scroll up to get to the original textbox, make your adjustments, and click "Navigate" again to start over.

+ + +

You can collapse either the Metrics or Visualizations sides of the dashboard to get a better view of the data. On the metrics side, you will see a short list of global network metrics, a histogram showing the frequency distribution of different node-level metrics, and a table showing each node and its metric values. (You'll also see download options, which we discuss below.)

+ + +

Clicking on the options above the histogram bar chart will show different graphs for each selected metric. These buttons will also update the size of the nodes in the force layout and arc diagram visualizations.

+ + +

Searching for specific nodes in the data table will also filter the visualization, making it easier to find the node you're looking for.

+ +

Read results with care! Some metrics will be affected by the type of graph you select. For example, in many smaller directed graphs, eigenvector centrality will be 0 for every node. Though this looks like an error, it's due to the nature of eigenvector centrality. When possible, Network Navigator displays error messages to explain some of these special cases.

+ +

Customize Visualizations

+ + +

One the right side of the screen, you have three different options for visualizations: clicking on "Force Layout," "Arc Diagram," and "Adjacency Matrix" will display these visualization types.

+ + +

You can scroll to zoom the Force Layout and Arc Diagram. In the Adjacency Matrix, you can click and drag to draw a box around the area you'd like to zoom into. In all visualizations, click the "Restore Zoom" button to return to the original display.

+ + +

Clicking "Customize Graph" will open a menu, different for each visualization type, that gives options for changing the appearance of the network. You can update the size or color of nodes, hide and show labels, change the order of nodes, and more.

+ + +

If your data had a header row and included more edge attributes, like edge weights, edge types, or timespans, you can filter the Force Layout and Arc Diagram based on those attributes. Select your desired attribute under "Filter by edge attribute" and navigate through the menus that appear.

+ +

Export and Download

+ + +

On the left side of the screen, beneath the global network metrics, is a set of options for download visualizations and data. Choose an option to download: a PNG or SVG of your current visualization view, a PNG of the current histogram, or a TXT file containing the global network metrics.

+ + +

You can also download the full node table as a CSV. To do this, scroll down to the node table and click "Download as CSV." You can also copy the data to the clipboard.

+ +

Last Updated: June 2021

+

files:
[{'sha': 'ccc62115aad3910d6e756a31d793ce1f023994c1', 'filename': 'README.md', 'status': 'added', 'additions': 7, 'deletions': 0, 'changes': 7, 'blob_url': 'https://github.com/jrladd/network_navigator/blob/062dc8db25f49916a45c29790cb4f4d684a5320c/README.md', 'raw_url': 'https://github.com/jrladd/network_navigator/raw/062dc8db25f49916a45c29790cb4f4d684a5320c/README.md', 'contents_url': 'https://api.github.com/repos/jrladd/network_navigator/contents/README.md?ref=062dc8db25f49916a45c29790cb4f4d684a5320c', 'patch': "@@ -0,0 +1,7 @@
+# Network Navigator
+
+This repository contains the code for *Network Navigator*, a browser tool designed for network analysis and built with humanities data in mind. It's meant as a bird's-eye-view of network metrics and some standard visualization forms, a way of exploring network data in classroom or research settings. Our intention is to emphasize the useful measurements and statistics that can be drawn from network data, while still providing the visualization tools offered by other network analysis software. *Network Navigator* was first released in 2017; the site was redesigned, expanded, and re-released as v2.0 in 2021.
+
+![](img/upload_data.gif)
+
+For more info, check out the [About](https://network-navigator.library.cmu.edu/about.html) and [How-To](https://network-navigator.library.cmu.edu/how-to.html) pages on our site."}]

commit.message: add gifs to how-to page
files:
[{'sha': 'e0f36cc011a584321097aa3ae040bcc28ba6f5fb', 'filename': 'how-to.html', 'status': 'modified', 'additions': 11, 'deletions': 1, 'changes': 12, 'blob_url': 'https://github.com/jrladd/network_navigator/blob/feaf2334376a070b0831c492645b28b3133514fe/how-to.html', 'raw_url': 'https://github.com/jrladd/network_navigator/raw/feaf2334376a070b0831c492645b28b3133514fe/how-to.html', 'contents_url': 'https://api.github.com/repos/jrladd/network_navigator/contents/how-to.html?ref=feaf2334376a070b0831c492645b28b3133514fe', 'patch': '@@ -28,6 +28,7 @@

How-To

Load Data

+

To load data into Network Navigator, type or drag-and-drop your edge list into the box. Use a CSV file or type your edges separated by commas, as below. (If you include a header row, the site will look for source, target, and weight columns, and it will keep track of any other columns you enter.)

@@ -49,31 +50,40 @@

Read Results

Clicking "Navigate" will load the network dashboard, with metrics on the left and visualizations on the right. If you need to make changes to the underlying data, you can scroll up to get to the original textbox, make your adjustments, and click "Navigate" again to start over.

+

You can collapse either the Metrics or Visualizations sides of the dashboard to get a better view of the data. On the metrics side, you will see a short list of global network metrics, a histogram showing the frequency distribution of different node-level metrics, and a table showing each node and its metric values. (You'll also see download options, which we discuss below.)

+

Clicking on the options above the histogram bar chart will show different graphs for each selected metric. These buttons will also update the size of the nodes in the force layout and arc diagram visualizations.

+

Searching for specific nodes in the data table will also filter the visualization, making it easier to find the node you're looking for.

Read results with care! Some metrics will be affected by the type of graph you select. For example, in many smaller directed graphs, eigenvector centrality will be 0 for every node. Though this looks like an error, it's due to the nature of eigenvector centrality. When possible, Network Navigator displays error messages to explain some of these special cases.

Customize Visualizations

+

One the right side of the screen, you have three different options for visualizations: clicking on "Force Layout," "Arc Diagram," and "Adjacency Matrix" will display these visualization types.

+

You can scroll to zoom the Force Layout and Arc Diagram. In the Adjacency Matrix, you can click and drag to draw a box around the area you'd like to zoom into. In all visualizations, click the "Restore Zoom" button to return to the original display.

+

Clicking "Customize Graph" will open a menu, different for each visualization type, that gives options for changing the appearance of the network. You can update the size or color of nodes, hide and show labels, change the order of nodes, and more.

+

If your data had a header row and included more edge attributes, like edge weights, edge types, or timespans, you can filter the Force Layout and Arc Diagram based on those attributes. Select your desired attribute under "Filter by edge attribute" and navigate through the menus that appear.

Export and Download

+

On the left side of the screen, beneath the global network metrics, is a set of options for download visualizations and data. Choose an option to download: a PNG or SVG of your current visualization view, a PNG of the current histogram, or a TXT file containing the global network metrics.

+

You can also download the full node table as a CSV. To do this, scroll down to the node table and click "Download as CSV." You can also copy the data to the clipboard.

-

Last Updated: May 2021

+

Last Updated: June 2021

files:
[{'sha': '075b218c360b8d93e56aced0a3bd1601fb006c8e', 'filename': '.index.html.swp', 'status': 'added', 'additions': 0, 'deletions': 0, 'changes': 0, 'blob_url': 'https://github.com/jrladd/network_navigator/blob/8f37cd170ff08bc53015b2f81a1108c7dc9c0373/.index.html.swp', 'raw_url': 'https://github.com/jrladd/network_navigator/raw/8f37cd170ff08bc53015b2f81a1108c7dc9c0373/.index.html.swp', 'contents_url': 'https://api.github.com/repos/jrladd/network_navigator/contents/.index.html.swp?ref=8f37cd170ff08bc53015b2f81a1108c7dc9c0373'}, {'sha': 'c46e0795357ef5b474e38db0dbd7496437724d30', 'filename': 'how-to.html', 'status': 'added', 'additions': 78, 'deletions': 0, 'changes': 78, 'blob_url': 'https://github.com/jrladd/network_navigator/blob/8f37cd170ff08bc53015b2f81a1108c7dc9c0373/how-to.html', 'raw_url': 'https://github.com/jrladd/network_navigator/raw/8f37cd170ff08bc53015b2f81a1108c7dc9c0373/how-to.html', 'contents_url': 'https://api.github.com/repos/jrladd/network_navigator/contents/how-to.html?ref=8f37cd170ff08bc53015b2f81a1108c7dc9c0373', 'patch': '@@ -0,0 +1,78 @@ + + + + + + + + Network Navigator How-To + + + + + + + + +
+
+

+ NETWORK NAVIGATOR v2.0 +

+
+
+
+

How-To

+

This page will walk you through the basics of Network Navigator, the browser tool designed for network metrics and visualization.

+ +

Load Data

+ +

To load data into Network Navigator, type or drag-and-drop your edge list into the box. Use a CSV file or type your edges separated by commas, as below. (If you include a header row, the site will look for source, target, and weight columns, and it will keep track of any other columns you enter.)

+ +

+ Person One,Person Two +Person Two,Person Three +Person Three,Person One

+ +

Your network can be either weighted or unweighted, and either directed or undirected. If your network is weighted, you'll need to add a third column to every line with the weight value:

+ +

Person One,Person Two,5

+ +

This site will work best with networks of up to 500 nodes and up to 10,000 edges, but networks of 250-500 edges will give the best visualization results. Networks larger than 500 nodes and ~10,000 edges may result in some slowdown of site functions.

+ +

n.b.: Network Navigator is currently only set up for unimodal (or unipartite) networks. While it will give results for any edge list, be advised that the metrics for bipartite networks aren't reliable.

+ +

Once you've typed or drag-and-dropped your data into the textbox and selected the appropriate options, you can click "Navigate" to display the dashboard for your network.

+ +

Read Results

+ +

Clicking "Navigate" will load the network dashboard, with metrics on the left and visualizations on the right. If you need to make changes to the underlying data, you can scroll up to get to the original textbox, make your adjustments, and click "Navigate" again to start over.

+ +

You can collapse either the Metrics or Visualizations sides of the dashboard to get a better view of the data. On the metrics side, you will see a short list of global network metrics, a histogram showing the frequency distribution of different node-level metrics, and a table showing each node and its metric values. (You'll also see download options, which we discuss below.)

+ +

Clicking on the options above the histogram bar chart will show different graphs for each selected metric. These buttons will also update the size of the nodes in the force layout and arc diagram visualizations.

+ +

Searching for specific nodes in the data table will also filter the visualization, making it easier to find the node you're looking for.

+ +

Customize Visualizations

+ +

One the right side of the screen, you have three different options for visualizations: clicking on "Force Layout," "Arc Diagram," and "Adjacency Matrix" will display these visualization types.

+ +

You can scroll to zoom the Force Layout and Arc Diagram. In the Adjacency Matrix, you can click and drag to draw a box around the area you'd like to zoom into. In all visualizations, click the "Restore Zoom" button to return to the original display.

+ +

Clicking "Customize Graph" will open a menu, different for each visualization type, that gives options for changing the appearance of the network. You can update the size or color of nodes, hide and show labels, change the order of nodes, and more.

+ +

If your data had a header row and included more edge attributes, like edge weights, edge types, or timespans, you can filter the Force Layout and Arc Diagram based on those attributes. Select your desired attribute under "Filter by edge attribute" and navigate through the menus that appear.

+ +

Export and Download

+ +

On the left side of the screen, beneath the global network metrics, is a set of options for download visualizations and data. Choose an option to download: a PNG or SVG of your current visualization view, a PNG of the current histogram, or a TXT file containing the global network metrics.

+ +

You can also download the full node table as a CSV. To do this, scroll down to the node table and click "Download as CSV." You can also copy the data to the clipboard.

+ +

Last Updated: May 2021

+
+ + +'}]

Network Navigator is a browser tool designed for network analysis, built with humanities data in mind. It's meant as a bird's-eye-view of network metrics and some standard visualization forms, a way of exploring network data in classroom or research settings. Network Navigator was first released in 2017; the site was redesigned, expanded, and re-released as v2.0 in 2021.

+

Network Navigator is a browser tool designed for network analysis, built with humanities data in mind. It's meant as a bird's-eye-view of network metrics and some standard visualization forms, a way of exploring network data in classroom or research settings. Our intention is to emphasize the useful measurements and statistics that can be drawn from network data, while still providing the visualization tools offered by other network analysis software. Network Navigator was first released in 2017; the site was redesigned, expanded, and re-released as v2.0 in 2021.

This website does not collect or store any data. Your data remains on your computer alone and is not sent to an external server. No one can view your data or results but you.

People

-
Show/Hide Instructions
-
- -

Network Navigator is designed to give you a first glimpse of your network data, with both metrics and visualizations. For more on who we are and how the site works, visit our About page.

- -

Type or drag-and-drop your edge list into the box below. Use a CSV file or type your edges separated by commas, like so (do not include a header row):

- -

- Person One,Person Two -Person Two,Person Three -Person Three,Person One

- -

Your network can be either weighted or unweighted, and either directed or undirected. If your network is weighted, you'll need to add a third column to every line with the weight value:

- -

Person One,Person Two,5

- -

This site will work best with networks of up to 500 nodes and up to 10,000 edges, but networks of 250-500 edges will give the best visualization results. Networks larger than 500 nodes and ~10,000 edges may result in some slowdown of site functions.

- -

n.b.: Network Navigator is currently only set up for unimodal (or unipartite) networks. While it will give results for any edge list, be advised that the metrics for bipartite networks aren't reliable.

- -

This website does not collect or store any data. Your data remains on your computer alone and is not sent to an external server. No one can view your data or results but you. -

- -

If you have comments or suggestions, or if anything's not working the way it should, feel free to reach out to John on Twitter.

- -
-

[{'sha': 'b76b87504dce44f12a6f47dc781a0f8c41ea4c41', 'filename': 'about.html', 'status': 'modified', 'additions': 0, 'deletions': 15, 'changes': 15, 'blob_url': 'https://github.com/jrladd/network_navigator/blob/40ee7c2f7c0deab4c27cea88eed71830dacedb59/about.html', 'raw_url': 'https://github.com/jrladd/network_navigator/raw/40ee7c2f7c0deab4c27cea88eed71830dacedb59/about.html', 'contents_url': 'https://api.github.com/repos/jrladd/network_navigator/contents/about.html?ref=40ee7c2f7c0deab4c27cea88eed71830dacedb59', 'patch': '@@ -40,21 +40,6 @@

Zoe LeBlanc

Zoe is currently a Postdoctoral Associate and Weld Fellow at the Center for Digital Humanities at Princeton University. She received her Ph.D. in History at Vanderbilt University in August 2019 and previously worked as a DH Developer at the Scholars' Lab at UVA.

Website. Twitter. Github. -

Next Steps

- -

For more information about managing network data and an introduction to the various network metrics used here, we recommend two Programming Historian tutorials: -

Creating Network Diagrams from Historical Sources

-

Exploring and Analyzing Network Data with Python

-

Once you've explored your network on our site, you may want to move to a more robust set of network analysis and visualization tools. We recommend the following:

-

NetworkX, a Python library

-

iGraph, an R library

-

Gephi, a desktop program

-

Cytoscape, a desktop program

-

D3 Force-Directed Graph, a JavaScript library with tools for network visualization

- -

For general guidance on network analysis and Python cultural analytics approaches, we recommend Melanie Walsh's Introduction to Cultural Analytics & Python and John Ladd's EarlyPrint + Python.

- -

Credits

We would like to thank Ruth and Sebastian Ahnert, Dan Evans, Doug Knox, Matt Lincoln, Steve Pentecost, Melanie Walsh, and Scott Weingart for their inspiration, suggestions, and feedback on this project.

Hosting and technical support for Network Navigator is generously supplied by:

+ NETWORK NAVIGATOR v2.0 +

Resources & Next Steps

+ +

For more information about managing network data and an introduction to the various network metrics used here, we recommend two Programming Historian tutorials: +

Creating Network Diagrams from Historical Sources

+

Exploring and Analyzing Network Data with Python

+
+

If you have bipartite or bimodal network data (a network that includes 2 kinds of entities, like one of authors and their books), you will need to project your data before you use Network Navigator. There is a quick tool for transforming your data here: +

The Project Project

+
+

Once you've explored your network on our site, you may want to move to a more robust set of network analysis and visualization tools. We recommend the following:

+

NetworkX, a Python library

+

iGraph, an R library

+

Gephi, a desktop program

+

Cytoscape, a desktop program

+

D3 Force-Directed Graph, a JavaScript library with tools for network visualization

+
+

For general guidance on network analysis and Python cultural analytics approaches, we recommend Melanie Walsh's Introduction to Cultural Analytics & Python and John Ladd's EarlyPrint + Python.

+ +

Last Updated: April 2021

+
+ + +'}]

[{'sha': '73b833ee1a856e1431421472ae53145cb5f898d8', 'filename': 'about.html', 'status': 'added', 'additions': 74, 'deletions': 0, 'changes': 74, 'blob_url': 'https://github.com/jrladd/network_navigator/blob/e4538fc6c3d440284ed0ee74961f9018d423bf6b/about.html', 'raw_url': 'https://github.com/jrladd/network_navigator/raw/e4538fc6c3d440284ed0ee74961f9018d423bf6b/about.html', 'contents_url': 'https://api.github.com/repos/jrladd/network_navigator/contents/about.html?ref=e4538fc6c3d440284ed0ee74961f9018d423bf6b', 'patch': '@@ -0,0 +1,74 @@ + + + + + + + + Network Navigator + + + + + + + + +
+
+

+ NETWORK NAVIGATOR v2.0 +

+
+
+
+

Network Navigator is a browser tool designed for network analysis, built with humanities data in mind. It's meant as a bird's-eye-view of network metrics and some standard visualization forms, a way of exploring network data in classroom or research settings. Network Navigator was first released in 2017; the site was redesigned, expanded, and re-released as v2.0 in 2021.

+

This website does not collect or store any data. Your data remains on your computer alone and is not sent to an external server. No one can view your data or results but you.

+ +

People

+
+ +

John Ladd

+
+

John is a postdoctoral fellow in Digital Humanities at Northwestern University. He specializes in network analysis and computational approaches to early modern literature. He's also worked on EarlyPrint, Six Degrees of Francis Bacon, and a range of other projects.

+

Website. Twitter. Github. +

+ +

Zoe LeBlanc

+
+

Zoe is currently a Postdoctoral Associate and Weld Fellow at the Center for Digital Humanities at Princeton University. She received her Ph.D. in History at Vanderbilt University in August 2019 and previously worked as a DH Developer at the Scholars' Lab at UVA.

+

Website. Twitter. Github. + +

Next Steps

+ +

For more information about managing network data and an introduction to the various network metrics used here, we recommend two Programming Historian tutorials: +

Creating Network Diagrams from Historical Sources

+

Exploring and Analyzing Network Data with Python

+

Once you've explored your network on our site, you may want to move to a more robust set of network analysis and visualization tools. We recommend the following:

+

NetworkX, a Python library

+

iGraph, an R library

+

Gephi, a desktop program

+

Cytoscape, a desktop program

+

D3 Force-Directed Graph, a JavaScript library with tools for network visualization

+ +

For general guidance on network analysis and Python cultural analytics approaches, we recommend Melanie Walsh's Introduction to Cultural Analytics & Python and John Ladd's EarlyPrint + Python.

+ + +

Credits

+

We would like to thank Ruth and Sebastian Ahnert, Dan Evans, Doug Knox, Matt Lincoln, Steve Pentecost, Melanie Walsh, and Scott Weingart for their inspiration, suggestions, and feedback on this project.

+

Hosting and technical support for Network Navigator is generously supplied by:

+

+ +

Code

+

The complete code for this site can be found in its Github repository.

+

Network Navigator makes use of the following libraries and stylesheets:

+

JSNetworkX, for calculating network metrics.

+

D3, for interactive visualizations.

+

DataTables, for handling tabular data and CSV export.

+

Tachyons, for styling and page layout.

+

Last Updated: March 2021

+

-

This tool is meant to provide a metrics-focused look into your network data. We hope it will be a quick - and easy way to get the most popular network measurements. While we provide a small visualization for - comparison purposes, visualization is not the focus. Instead, we hope the sortable tables will allow you - to assess and navigate your network in new ways.

+

Network Navigator is designed to give you a first glimpse of your network data, with both metrics and visualizations. For more on who we are and how the site works, visit our About page.

-

Next Steps

Cytoscape, a desktop program

D3 Force-Directed Graph, a JavaScript library with tools for network visualization

+

For general guidance on network analysis and Python cultural analytics approaches, we recommend Melanie Walsh's Introduction to Cultural Analytics & Python and John Ladd's EarlyPrint + Python.

+

Credits

We would like to thank Ruth and Sebastian Ahnert, Dan Evans, Doug Knox, Matt Lincoln, Steve Pentecost, Melanie Walsh, and Scott Weingart for their inspiration, suggestions, and feedback on this project.

D3, for interactive visualizations.

DataTables, for handling tabular data and CSV export.

Tachyons, for styling and page layout.

+

Last Updated: March 2021

files:
[{'sha': '0638cc62c6ce2e7f0f37e6f533957daffbff2430', 'filename': 'about.html', 'status': 'added', 'additions': 74, 'deletions': 0, 'changes': 74, 'blob_url': 'https://github.com/jrladd/network_navigator/blob/59f0216f8869cf2ab7f5bd1b96294c821e203265/about.html', 'raw_url': 'https://github.com/jrladd/network_navigator/raw/59f0216f8869cf2ab7f5bd1b96294c821e203265/about.html', 'contents_url': 'https://api.github.com/repos/jrladd/network_navigator/contents/about.html?ref=59f0216f8869cf2ab7f5bd1b96294c821e203265', 'patch': '@@ -0,0 +1,74 @@ + + + + + + + + Network Navigator + + + + + + + + +
+
+

+ NETWORK NAVIGATOR v2.0 +

+
+
+
+

Network Navigator is a browser tool designed for network analysis, built with humanities data in mind. It's meant as a bird's-eye-view of network metrics and some standard visualization forms, a way of exploring network data in classroom or research settings. Network Navigator was first released in 2017; the site was redesigned, expanded, and re-released as v2.0 in 2021.

+

This website does not collect or store any data. Your data remains on your computer alone and is not sent to an external server. No one can view your data or results but you.

+ +

People

+
+ +

John Ladd

+
+

John is a postdoctoral fellow in Digital Humanities at Northwestern University. He specializes in network analysis and computational approaches to early modern literature. He's also worked on EarlyPrint, Six Degrees of Francis Bacon, and a range of other projects.

+

Website. Twitter. Github. +

+ +

Zoe LeBlanc

+
+

Zoe ...

+

Website. Twitter. Github. + +

Next Steps

+ +

For more information about managing network data and an introduction to the various network metrics used here, we recommend two Programming Historian tutorials: +

Creating Network Diagrams from Historical Sources

+

Exploring and Analyzing Network Data with Python

+

Once you've explored your network on our site, you may want to move to a more robust set of network analysis and visualization tools. We recommend the following:

+

NetworkX, a Python library

+

iGraph, an R library

+

Gephi, a desktop program

+

Cytoscape, a desktop program

+

D3 Force-Directed Graph, a JavaScript library with tools for network visualization

+ + +

Credits

+

We would like to thank Ruth and Sebastian Ahnert, Dan Evans, Doug Knox, Matt Lincoln, Steve Pentecost, Melanie Walsh, and Scott Weingart for their inspiration, suggestions, and feedback on this project.

+

Hosting and technical support for Network Navigator is generously supplied by:

+

+ +

Code

+

The complete code for this site can be found in its Github repository.

+

Network Navigator makes use of the following libraries and stylesheets:

+

JSNetworkX, for calculating network metrics.

+

D3, for interactive visualizations.

+

DataTables, for handling tabular data and CSV export.

+

Tachyons, for styling and page layout.

+

+ About

Show/Hide Instructions

Show/Hide Instructions
+
-

This tool is meant to provide a metrics-focused look into your network data. We hope it will be a quick - and easy way to get the most popular network measurements. While we provide a small visualization for - comparison purposes, visualization is not the focus. Instead, we hope the sortable tables will allow you - to assess and navigate your network in new ways.

+

Network Navigator is designed to give you a first glimpse of your network data, with both metrics and visualizations. For more on who we are and how the site works, visit our About page.

-

Type or drag-and-drop your edge list into the box below. Use a CSV file or type your edges separated by - commas, like so (do not include a header row):

+

Type or drag-and-drop your edge list into the box below. Use a CSV file or type your edges separated by commas, like so (do not include a header row):

-

+

Person One,Person Two - Person Two,Person Three - Person Three,Person One

+Person Two,Person Three +Person Three,Person One

-

Your network can be either weighted or unweighted, and either directed or undirected. If your network is - weighted, you'll need to add a third column to every line with the weight value:

+

Your network can be either weighted or unweighted, and either directed or undirected. If your network is weighted, you'll need to add a third column to every line with the weight value:

-

Person One,Person Two,5

+

Person One,Person Two,5

-

For more information about managing network data and an introduction to the various network metrics used - here, we recommend two Programming Historian tutorials: Creating Network Diagrams from Historical Sources and Exploring and Analyzing Network Data. n.b.: Network Navigator is currently only - set up for unimodal (or unipartite) networks. While it will give results for any edge list, be advised - that the metrics for bipartite networks aren't reliable.

+

Network Navigator is a browser tool designed for network analysis, built with humanities data in mind. It's meant as a bird's-eye-view of network metrics and some standard visualization forms, a way of exploring network data in classroom or research settings. Network Navigator was first released in 2017; the site was redesigned, expanded, and re-released as v2.0 in 2021.

+

Network Navigator is a browser tool designed for network analysis, built with humanities data in mind. It's meant as a bird's-eye-view of network metrics and some standard visualization forms, a way of exploring network data in classroom or research settings. Network Navigator was first released in 2017; the site was redesigned, expanded, and re-released as v2.0 in 2021.

+

This website does not collect or store any data. Your data remains on your computer alone and is not sent to an external server. No one can view your data or results but you.

People

John Ladd

John is a postdoctoral fellow in Digital Humanities at Northwestern University. He specializes in network analysis and computational approaches to early modern literature. He's also worked on EarlyPrint, Six Degrees of Francis Bacon, and a range of other projects.

-

Website. Github. +

Website. Twitter. Github.

Zoe LeBlanc

Zoe ...

-

Website. Github. +

Website. Twitter. Github. + +

Next Steps

+ +

For more information about managing network data and an introduction to the various network metrics used here, we recommend two Programming Historian tutorials: +

Creating Network Diagrams from Historical Sources

+

Exploring and Analyzing Network Data with Python

+

Once you've explored your network on our site, you may want to move to a more robust set of network analysis and visualization tools. We recommend the following:

+

NetworkX, a Python library

+

iGraph, an R library

+

Gephi, a desktop program

+

Cytoscape, a desktop program

+

D3 Force-Directed Graph, a JavaScript library with tools for network visualization

+

Credits

We would like to thank Ruth and Sebastian Ahnert, Dan Evans, Doug Knox, Matt Lincoln, Steve Pentecost, Melanie Walsh, and Scott Weingart for their inspiration, suggestions, and feedback on this project.

This tool is meant to provide a metrics-focused look into your network data. We hope it will be a quick - and easy way to get the most popular network measurements. While we provide a small visualization for - comparison purposes, visualization is not the focus. Instead, we hope the sortable tables will allow you - to assess and navigate your network in new ways.

+

Network Navigator is designed to give you a first glimpse of your network data, with both metrics and visualizations. For more on who we are and how the site works, visit our About page.

-

Type or drag-and-drop your edge list into the box below. Use a CSV file or type your edges separated by - commas, like so (do not include a header row):

+

Type or drag-and-drop your edge list into the box below. Use a CSV file or type your edges separated by commas, like so (do not include a header row):

-

+

Person One,Person Two - Person Two,Person Three - Person Three,Person One

+Person Two,Person Three +Person Three,Person One

-

Your network can be either weighted or unweighted, and either directed or undirected. If your network is - weighted, you'll need to add a third column to every line with the weight value:

+

Your network can be either weighted or unweighted, and either directed or undirected. If your network is weighted, you'll need to add a third column to every line with the weight value:

-

Person One,Person Two,5

+

Person One,Person Two,5

-

For more information about managing network data and an introduction to the various network metrics used - here, we recommend two Programming Historian tutorials: Creating Network Diagrams from Historical Sources and Exploring and Analyzing Network Data. n.b.: Network Navigator is currently only - set up for unimodal (or unipartite) networks. While it will give results for any edge list, be advised - that the metrics for bipartite networks aren't reliable.

+

n.b.: Network Navigator is currently only set up for unimodal (or unipartite) networks. While it will give results for any edge list, be advised that the metrics for bipartite networks aren't reliable.

-

This website does not collect or store any data. Your data remains on your computer - alone and is not sent to an external server. No one can view your data or results but you. +

If you have comments or suggestions, feel free to say hello on Twitter.

+
+
+

Network Navigator is a browser tool designed for network analysis, built with humanities data in mind. It's meant as a bird's-eye-view of network metrics and some standard visualization forms, a way of exploring network data in classroom or research settings. Network Navigator was first released in 2017; the site was redesigned, expanded, and re-released as v2.0 in 2021.

+ +

People

+
+ +

John Ladd

+
+

John is a postdoctoral fellow in Digital Humanities at Northwestern University. He specializes in network analysis and computational approaches to early modern literature. He's also worked on EarlyPrint, Six Degrees of Francis Bacon, and a range of other projects.

Credits

We would like to thank Ruth and Sebastian Ahnert, Dan Evans, Doug Knox, Matt Lincoln, Steve Pentecost, Melanie Walsh, and Scott Weingart for their inspiration, suggestions, and feedback on this project.

+

Hosting and technical support for Network Navigator is generously supplied by:

+

+ +

Code

+

The complete code for this site can be found in its Github repository.

+

Network Navigator makes use of the following libraries and stylesheets:

+

JSNetworkX, for calculating network metrics.

+

D3, for interactive visualizations.

+

DataTables, for handling tabular data and CSV export.

+

Tachyons, for styling and page layout.

Show/Hide Instructions

This tool is meant to provide a metrics-focused look into your network data. We hope it will be a quick and easy way to get the most popular network measurements. While we provide a small visualization for comparison purposes, visualization is not the focus. Instead, we hope the sortable tables will allow you to assess and navigate your network in new ways.

Too many/too few values! One or more of the rows in your data has the wrong number of values. For unweighted networks, your rows can have two or three values: source,target or source,target,weight. For weighted networks, each row must have three values: source,target,weight. Please edit your data and try again.

+
+ Skipping Eigenvector Centrality: Your network has no closed loops, so eigenvector centrality cannot be calculated. +

@@ -135,13 +130,10 @@

- +
